Key Arguments: The proposed bill is undemocratic and contravenes the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR).
The bill is poorly drafted with undefined key terms, particularly regarding who determines what constitutes misinformation and disinformation.
The government already has existing means to address genuine threats to national security, fraud, and incitement to violence.
The bill infringes on freedom of speech and expression as enshrined in Article 19 of the ICCPR.
Notable Quotes: The proposed bill is undemocratic, it is badly drafted with poorly-defined key terms, and in direct contravention of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
The government already has the means to take actions on genuine threats to national security, on fraud, and on speech which incites violence.

It is already unacceptable, if not treasonous that the government is seeking to regulate the speech of Australians; the fact that this regulation will be enforced using a completely non-transparent process should raise concerns of all Australians.

The draft Bill directly contravenes the second of these rights, by seeking to impose restrictions on the types of information that individuals can seek, receive and share, based on poorly defined categories of potential or putative 'harm'.
